From: "dph of rules " <dph_of_rules@...>

Actually, I made a mispelling instead of typing 'omnipotence' I 
tped 'impotence'.  I am serious about limits to prevent omnipotent 
characters.  2nd, I beat the ocean by freezing time with my mage.  I 
still have not figured how that worked.  3rd, my mega-archmage can 
summon fire elementals that can not be harmed.  Theoritically, I could 
continously teleport and be unharmed in the ocean until I find one 
spot to land.

4th, there is a big difference between my levels and Tryx:  you can 
navigate all of my levels without relying on ghosts, mages, or 
archmages.  All of the levels have reasonably packed enemies.  At no 
present time, any player is severely in trouble if they follow the 
main path (ie. Archer encampment and Slime Lords are off the path) 
because of being outnumbered.  I redid my first scenario [translation: 
 made it easier] because my team was overwhelmed at the start.

Actually, I have a theory about how much armor an archer needs to 
protect himself.  Multiply the strength of the archer times the 
experience level of the archer and use the result as the minimum 
recommended amount of armor.  Of course, I have to test against a 
mega-archer.

I would put my illegitimate mega-archmage up against anything except 
powerfull mages [because they could freee time continiously and wipe 
anybody out that way], no matter how outnumbered or how powerfull the 
opponents are (even against an experience level 400 anything, an 
indestructible fire elemental with unlimited can take it out).  
Considering that he can summon indestructible fire elementals, all one 
would need do is summon a few fire elementals and then continiously 
teleport.

I have a working theory that high-experience and high intelligence 
level mage could take anything out, if you had the time to spend 
(hours and days).  Just keep time frozen.  Also, by freezing time, you 
can prevent archmages from overloading your computer with chain 
lightning.  Playing my scenarios is ONLY advised if you have a fast 
processor and lots and lots of RAM if you intend on using 
chain-lightning.

Heck, I thought I tested everything on my own scenarios and realized I 
made a few mistakes.
